column2: Seaford's weather is moderated by the Atlantic Ocean.  Seaford has a mild subtropical climate consisting of hot
column3: humid summers and mild winters.  The average daytime high in July is 87 °F (30.6 °C) and a low of 65 °F (18.3 °C); in January
column4: the average high is 44 °F (6.7 °C) with an average low of 25 °F (-3.9 °C)   The month of highest average rainfall is August with 5.59 inches (142.0 mm) of rain
column5: while February is historically the driest month
column6: receiving an average of only 3.17 inches (80.5 mm) of rain.The highest official temperature ever recorded in Seaford was 104 °F (40.0 °C) on July 22
column8: while the all-time low was -13 °F (-25.0 °C) on January 28

column1: Seaford has a mayor-council system of government with a mayor and a city council. As of 2017
column2: the mayor of Seaford is David Genshaw
column3: Dan H. Henderson is vice mayor
column4: and the other members of the city council are Grace S. Peterson

column1: U.S. Route 13 is the main north-south thoroughfare within city limits
column2: with Delaware Route 20 being the main east-west highway.  U.S. Route 13 connects Seaford with Bridgeville to the north and Laurel to the south as part of the Sussex Highway.  State Route 20 connects Seaford with Millsboro to the east and tiny Reliance
column3: Maryland to the west.

column1: The closest airport with commercial air service to Seaford is the Wicomico Regional Airport in Salisbury
column2: Maryland. The closest public airport is Laurel Airport in Laurel
column3: Delaware. There is also an airport in Georgetown called the Delaware Coastal Airport.  This airport has a jet service section
column4: as part of the nearby industrial park.

column1: DART First State operates the Route 212 bus that connects Seaford to Georgetown and Delmar and the Route 903F bus that runs on a loop through Seaford.Freight rail service in Seaford is provided by two carriers: the Delmarva Central Railroad and the Maryland and Delaware Railroad.  The Delmarva Central Railroad runs north-south through the city
column2: parallel to US 13. It interchanges with the Maryland and Delaware Railroad in Seaford
column3: which heads west to Federalsburg and Cambridge in Maryland.

column1: The City of Seaford Electric Department provides electricity to about 6
column2: 700 customers in the city. The electric department owns 3 substations and more than 37 miles (60 km) of transmission and distribution lines. The city purchases its electricity and is a member of the Delaware Municipal Electric Corporation. The Public Works department provides water and sewer service to the city. Natural gas service in Seaford is provided by Chesapeake Utilities.

column1: Nanticoke Memorial Hospital and the Nanticoke Cancer Care Center
column2: both operated by Nanticoke Health Services
column3: are located in Seaford.

column1: Students in Seaford are offered a number of public and private school choices.
Seaford is home to the Seaford School District and services children in the Seaford
column2: Blades
column3: Concord
column5: and Woodland.  The District contains four elementary schools
column6: one middle school and Seaford Senior High School.

column1: The only radio station calling Seaford its home is WGBG 92.7 FM
column2: which broadcasts from just outside the city limits. It plays conservative talk radio personalities such as Rush Limbaugh
column3: Mark Levin

column1: Legendary disc jockey Bill Crisp at one time owned the only AM/FM radio stations licensed to Seaford
column2: WSFD/WSUX. Their studios were located on S. Dual Highway just two miles south of Seaford. WSFD broadcast on a frequency of 1280 AM as a daytime only radio station with 1000 watts of power serving Lower Delaware. Some of its formats included Adult Contemporary and Country. The station went dark in the late 1990s. WSUX broadcast 3000 watts on a frequency of 98.3 FM and was known as Stereo 98. The station survived years of popularity in the 70s and 80s with a Top 40 format serving Maryland's Eastern Shore and Lower Delaware. The station was later sold and has since switched frequency to 98.5.

column1: WDPB-TV 64 is the only television station originating from Seaford.  It is a subsidiary of WHYY-TV in Philadelphia and an affiliate of PBS.
Seaford is home to one weekly newspaper
column2: the Seaford Star.  The Seaford Star is a publication of Morning Star Publications
column3: Inc.
column4: which is owned by Seaford residents Bryant and Carol Richardson. The newspaper retails for 50 cents per issue and is also available by subscription.

column1: Seaford Christmas Parade – The biggest Christmas Parade on the Delmarva Peninsula. It is a night time parade
column2: on the first Saturday of December.

column1: Seaford Museum – the Seaford Museum is in the historic former post office and serves as a repository for items of significance in the history of Seaford; collections and exhibits highlight Seaford area history from Native Americans to present day; the original map of Seaford is on display.
Ross Mansion and Plantation – former residence of former Delaware Governor William H. H. Ross; it is a 20-acre (81
column2: 000 m2) property that includes in addition to the Mansion
column3: a granary with farm equipment exhibits
column5: a Victorian cottage and Delaware's only documented log slave quarters; the Mansion is a brick Italian Villa style structure completed in 1859; it is furnished in authentic Victorian style with many pieces having belonged to the Ross family.

column1: Nanticoke Riverfest takes place the second weekend in July and the Nanticoke River is used for inner tube floating. There is also a three-day festival. The Carnival opens Thursday. Friday evening and all day Saturday merchants and vendors sell their products on High Street. Free concerts with live bands perform Friday night and Saturday night. There is also a Miss Riverfest Pageant for teenagers to enter
column2: and a Little Miss Riverfest pageant for younger children to enter.

column1: The AFRAM Festival is a celebration of African American culture which is held the second weekend of August in Nutter Park.
Woodland Ferry – located west of Seaford
column2: the ferry operates sunup to sundown
column3: seven days a week with no fare charged; the 200-year-old cable-run ferry boat crossing the Nanticoke River
column4: one of the last remaining ferries on the East Coast

column1: Patty Cannon House – located outside of Seaford in Reliance
column2: Delaware (formerly Johnson's Cross Roads)
column3: this house is where the noted kidnapping group including Patty Cannon had its headquarters; the group was involved in robbery and entrapment of free blacks in the area; this house was ideal because of its location: one side sits in Maryland while the other side sits in Delaware; today
column4: the house still stands and is a historical landmark.
